repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Inspired by #24564, deprecating and removing our usages of this troublesome function.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -459,6 +459,7 @@ end
 --- ``tbl_add_reverse_lookup { A = 1 } == { [1] = 'A', A = 1 }``
 ---
 --- Note that this *modifies* the input.
+---@deprecated

comment_data.body: My point was actually to _not_ shoehorn the reverse lookup into the _same_ table. Can we make this a separate table?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -80,9 +81,10 @@ end
 for level, levelnr in pairs(log.levels) do
   -- Also export the log level on the root object.
   log[level] = levelnr
-end
 
-vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup(log.levels)
+  -- Add a reverse lookup.

@@ -80,9 +81,10 @@ end
 for level, levelnr in pairs(log.levels) do

   log[level] = levelnr
-end

comment_regular_data.body: This is not a breaking change.

Ehhh what's going on with the docs check?

EDIT: Nvm.

> CI looks sad.

Yeah, I'm waiting for it to cheer up.

For those who might find this issue by searching the web: to avoid using the deprecated function, one might write a (simple) for loop. Here is an alternative implementation:

```lua
for _, k in ipairs(vim.tbl_keys(t)) do
  t[t[k]] = k
end
```
(or you can make a *shallow* copy of a table, and run a loop with `pairs`)

Note: Do not update the same table while iterating through it. It will often work incorrectly:
```lua
-- XXX this is buggy!
for k, v in pairs(t) do
  t[v] = k
end
```
